abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the National Oilseed
            Development Project for Pakistan was satisfactory. The
            project achieved its main objectives, its impact on
            institutional development was partially successful,
            sustainability is uncertain at this time, and the
            performance of both the Bank and Borrower was satisfactory.
            Several lessons can be learned from this project. First, the
            project was too complex in design. In hindsight, encouraging
            farmers to form "producers organizations" for
            addressing their crop disposal issues and to foster better
            linkages with extension agents for production technology
            uptake could have assisted in better performance. Second,
            monopolistic tendencies of the GCP as well as price control
            regimes of the Government hampered the development of
            efficient marketing channels. Third, credit did not work as
            an incentive for the promotion of oilseed crops as
            envisioned in the project. Fourth, the Bank's
            supervision missions should have been more frequent for such
            a complex project to succeed. Finally, aggressive awareness
            initiatives should have been built into the project.
